147382699.review:
[h1] Good Game [/h1]

I finished this game in around six hours. I really enjoyed the art style. The animations, strange worlds and bosses were all nice to look at. The game has really simple gameplay consisting mostly of activating different devices in a certain order to get to the next area. The central mechanic was interesting(traveling in and out of different orbs to solve puzzles), unfortunately the puzzles only truly got me to think about them a few times and were never very difficult to figure out. i wish the game had focused a bit more on creating more complex or interesting puzzles to use the games central mechanic. maybe having optional side areas with more difficult puzzles could have provided a better challenge to someone like me that plays a lot of puzzle games

The central mechanic in this game reminds me of another puzzle game i have played Patricks Parabox, in comparison Cocoon feels more like style over substance. Patricks parabox in compaarison is much uglier but has much better designed puzzles using a similar central mechanic to cocoon but uses it much better by focusing solely on the puzzles and continuously added more and more complicated puzzles. Maybe if cocoon has spent a bit more time on the puzzles instead of the art styles it may have been more engaging. The final puzzle in cocoon is underwhelming because it is so easy. if the game had built on the challenge better and ended with a unique and challenging puzzle it would have left a much bigger impact on me

i recommend if you think you would enjoy a pretty game with simple to novice puzzles. Might be great for you if you want a short pretty and simple experience

147381551.review: The Inside devs really took the criticism to heart and have us actually go inside this time...a lot.

147380768.review:
Beautiful yet short puzzle game by brilliant Jeppe Carlsen (of INSIDE fame). Every aspect of the game is polished and satisfying:
- The music elevates tension, guides the player and rewards when taking the right path/solving puzzles. 
- The art style is a mesmerizing bio-mechanical and at times Escher-esque, all the while sneaking peeks of a vast unobtainable world. 
- The puzzle design is simple and ramps up in complexity as the game progresses, I was was stumped for a while on one or two puzzles but on the whole felt it was mostly straightforward and easily understandable. I guess I would have liked some harder or more mind bending puzzles (though I am a fan of puzzle games and played quite a lot of them)
- As I've mentioned, the game is pretty short - finished it completely (including all achievements) in under 5 hours. On the one hand I fell like I would've liked more, yet on the other hand it was a very concentrated and curated experience. This is the only part where if you are not a fanatic of Carlsen's or of puzzle games might want to consider if the price to game to time ratio is enough for you. In my opinion it is very much worth my money.
A uniquely gorgeous experience, one that at least on the puzzle side is very close to portal, and transports you to an artfully imaginative world. Can't wait to see what Carlsen and his team create next!

147379769.review:
Amazing, short, surreal puzzle game in an alien world. Took me a bit over 4 hours to complete. Probably best to go in with knowing as little as possible.

Just a really well designed game. I loved how everything is taught to you intuitively. All you do is move and press A to interact.
The boss fights were one of my favourite parts, they just throw you a completely new gameplay mechanic that you never use again after that.

It's not a very demanding puzzler, it does get gradually more complex but I never felt stumped. Instead of "daymn I'm clever" it's more like a "daymn this game is clever" type of game.

147379464.review: So good - a masterfully created experience. Just blown away by the quality. This fits in well with games like INSIDE, ABZU, Journey, and LIMBO. You would like it even if you haven't played those titles.

147379402.review: One of the best mid-warping puzzle game I've ever played. It provides a unique experience with an utterly satisfying game design.

147377730.review: Good game. Enjoyable. Short, but enjoyable.

147377537.review: Great game. It's short but every moment in it makes it worth it.

147374161.review:
Cocoon is an impeccably designed puzzle game with excellent art direction, but the narrative and the world felt lacking.

I had a great time blasting through the whole thing in one sitting, but I don't think this will be lingering with me for long -- certainly not in the way INSIDE did.

A worthwhile four-hour snack of a game, if nothing else.

I only really had to think hard in the last 30mins or so, but that again is no real complaint. I suppose you could be critical that it follows the abstract-alien-puzzle-wordless setting thats is fairly common for these sort of games.. But it does it so well that I can forgive it! 147358386.review:
This is easily the game of the year, and this could be one of my favourite game of all time (if not the best game ever made). Former Playdead Gameplay Designer Jeppe Carlsen and Audio Programmer Jakob Schmid literally knocked it out of the park, these were one of the talented people behind LIMBO and INSIDE (which both were my fav game ever), they have skills and experience and they know what they were doing!

147358092.review:
I tumbled through COCOON in most of an evening and the early hours of the next morning, finishing the game in just under the 6 hour mark, compelled forwards by one of the most intriguing videogame worlds I've explored in a while. Before we get started: if I see a single complaint about this game being 'too short for the price', I'm going to explode; COCOON, like few other games, maximises every minute to show you something new, and reminds us what games can be when we take the risk to pursue the original.

COCOON reminds me of a number of games: the wide-eyed wonder and revelations of Outer Wilds, the pick-up-and-put-down trial-and-error puzzling of Wind Waker's later dungeons, the alien environment of... well, it's hard to pick just one, as COCOON journeys you through the macro and the micro, stretching your mind like taffy to comprehend where and when you might be. Without the strong environmental and art design holding it together, you'd get whiplash, but as it stands, worlds which begin novel become familiar over time - which, as it turns out, is key to the gameplay.

The puzzling premise, here, is diving in and out of glass orbs, each of which contains a world. To keep it as spoiler-free as possible, you soon discover these glass orbs are the core of your puzzling power, as well as the road your journey takes place on. Just as you feel you've discovered the limit of how they can be used, COCOON nudges you a little further, encouraging you to take that mental leap of faith to find a new path forwards.

And it really is that - a polite nudge. At no point did I feel like I was headbutting a brick wall in my puzzle-solving. I'm an impatient puzzler, and struggle to get my head around layered puzzles, but COCOON is kind, ensuring I understood the bounds of each puzzle by limiting my area of play, and nearly all frustration is allayed by the feeling that the game wouldn't play tricks on me, or bait me with red herrings. I dislike puzzles of this sort, so if you do, too, you'll hopefully find COCOON is a good balance of puzzle versus progress.

There are some brief moments of true frustration, though. For instance, one series of solutions relied heavily on timing, which felt mildly incongruous with the puzzles up until that point. But it wasn't by any means enough to shatter my immersion: and what a world to be immersed in. 

COCOON is minimalist. A 5-key control system has you absorbed within moments, the need to learn complex key-binds eliminated. COCOON toys with scale, colour, flora and fauna, perspective, shape, so on and so forth, to communicate lore in what is otherwise a wordless, speechless game, and it's at its best for it. 

COCOON knows exactly what it is, does that extremely well, and leaves you as a player wondering what on earth - or not, as the case may be - you just experienced as you surface for air at its completion.

It's very good.

147354584.review: This feels like playing Portal for the first time again

147354322.review:
I absolutely enjoyed COCOON. 
While the game is not long at all, clocking around 4 hours for me for 100% completion, I really liked the puzzles, the music and atmosphere. The idea of jumping between worlds is used nicely and doesn't feel bad. The game cleverly reduces the parts of the world you're allowed to travel to so that one doesn't get lost. In several circumstances I was surprised by a new mechanic I didn't expect.

I just wish that the game would be a bit longer (like 1-2h) so that some concepts can get more time to shine. Even optional (hard) puzzles would be nice.

All in all, this game is great if you want to spend a few hours, get all achievements and be done with it afterwards.

147351727.review:
tried cocoon for an hour, completed two worlds, felt that I need to take a break to get my thoughts together

- animations and visuals are outstanding. you get what you see in the trailer and even more. pure magic
- puzzles felt good: not too easy, not too hard, constantly making you feel clever. unique setting makes it feel that while you're solving the puzzles, you're also exploring how the game world works, that's cool
- guidance to out-of-the-box-thinking moments is top-notch
- loved that design-wise, boxes mostly move in their designed lines, but controlling interface makes it feel like you have some directional freedom. this feels amazing and does not brake puzzles by giving players too much freedom. super clever stuff
- bosses are too similar to Mario bosses and their stages. they clearly provide a good change of pace, but for me they felt weird, mostly because it was not what I expected from the auteur-indie project
- worldbuilding and unique setting suggest that the game has something more to tell than a set of abstract puzzles. maybe that happens later, but I have not seen that yet, so felt a bit disengaged

the game is marketed as a project of a gameplay programmer who worked on Limbo and Inside, and, comparing to them, it feels as a solid solo-album. from that perspective, gameplay design and execution are top-notch, and that's what was this game is about and that’s what matters here

my main concerns are the lack of story and the lack of understanding of a bigger picture of where am I in the gameplay progression and what my actions mean, so it felt like i'm solving whatever obstacles the game is throwing at me, for the sake of it. and “it” here is feeling good about the beautiful world, perfect character-camera-controls and magical puzzles. and that's good, I do recommend this game as an exceptionally beautiful abstract puzzle!

147351509.review: It might have head and body of "Limbo" and "Inside" (Jeppe Carlsen), but it doesn't have its soul (Arnt Jensen). It's disingenuous to ride on the hype of the Playdead games because "Cocoon" is nothing to compare with them. There's no story, no emotion. You just do stuff because you can or because it blocks you from doing other stuff without any point or explanation. There's no satisfaction in resolving puzzles. Every puzzle had me like: "Oh, it's like this. Ok, I guess, whatever". It's Inception-like traversals don't bring anything to the gameplay, but it's just a gimmick which looks "cool" in the trailer. I think I'll try "Somerville" instead despite its negative reviews.

147328650.review: Outstanding puzzle game with very unique look. Highly recommended.

147328441.review:
Perfect puzzle game.

Really. I don't just say these things.
Geometric Interactive has tuned this work of art to a fine point. It completely absorbed me and I already want to experience it again.

The control scheme is deceptively simple (movement plus one button), and yet the mechanics develop depth that continued to surprise me until the end of the game. When you think you have it all figured out, something comes up and you realize your tools can do more and more.

All of this woven into one of the most beautiful minimal tapestries I have seen in a game of this budget level.

Just buy it and play it. Don't look it up. Don't use a guide.
It isn't very long (took me less than five hours), nor is it very hard, but you have never played a game like this.

Overall, I really enjoyed the puzzle designs, aesthetic and mood, and music. Recommend for anyone who wants a breezy puzzler that can be completed in one sitting.

147322052.review:
If you have a background in puzzle games (in particular Patrick's Parabox or Recursed), Cocoon might feel too easy, that being said it's still a good adventure game with great vibes all around.

I liked how the only prompt I've seen for the whole game was to press "A" on the main menu, beside the joystick, this is actually the only button that will be used for everything in the game. 
There isn't either any ui on the play screen, the only words you'll ever see are in the main and the pause menu.

I expected more from the puzzling aspect of Cocoon but it completely delivered on its vibes and overall I had a very good time. If the trailer entices you, it's a very safe bet.

147320074.review:
An enjoyable puzzle game wrapped in a biomechanical skin that looks incredible, and an amazing soundtrack as well. None of the puzzles have been too challenging so far, but some of them do make you stop and think for just a moment, not a frustrating amount of time by any means. Lack of tutorial but purposefully so, and introduces new concepts organically.

The only real con to the game I notice so far is that it's a short game, but sometimes that's all it takes. I haven't beaten it yet but judging from the reviews of others and the rate I'm gathering achievements, seems to be a 3-5 hr experience.

147318178.review:
This is another game to add to the list of short art experiences that are well worth the price of admission. Think Artful Escape, Gris, and of course Limbo and Inside. Annapurna Interactive sure knows how to pick who and what to publish because this game deserves all of the love that its getting. 

There is legitimately not a single part of this game that I can knock. I don't dislike any part of it and thats coming from someone that DESPISES puzzles and puzzle games. The puzzle design and general gameplay felt very good, forcing me to think outside the box a good bit but still very much playing within its own ruleset. 

The best part of this game though is not the gameplay but the presentation, art direction and music all working in harmony. If you are a little wary that the trailers are just showing the good parts of the game? Yeah, those are the boring parts in the trailer, actually. There is a visual feast on display that absolutely blows you away when it gets paired with the atmospheric sound design and a fantastic soundtrack that really does a good job pacing the game out and setting the tone as you move through it. 

It's hard for a puzzle game to increase in complexity without getting overly complex, but Cocoon managed to not only increase the loose narrative stakes throughout the game, but it also gradually increased the complexity of puzzles in an impressive way that kept surprising me. I love how they used the mechanics like building blocks ending with some genuine brain tickling tests that force you to use all of the tools available to you and show that you were in fact not getting lucky up to that point, but understanding EXACTLY how the puzzle mechanics worked. That being said, it was again, very fair and unfrustrating to work through. 

For completionists, there is a function after you beat the game that allows you to go back to any specific point in the game to acquire all of the things you were missing so don't focus too hard on the extra stuff your first playthrough if you wanna get all achievements, just have a good time and enjoy yourself and you can go back later to find what you need. (It also has a statue that shows you where and what you are missing for the extra goodies so no need to guess where stuff is)

I wish I had more to say beyond, "Hey, this kicks ass", but I don't. This is precisely what is advertised on the outside of the box and does a great job at providing surprises the whole way through that keeps you intrigued and engaged. This is one of those sleeper games that won't get mentioned come GOTY time but absolutely deserves a nod for being fantastic in 2023, a year that is jam PACKED with great games.

Easily recommended. 

Follow my steam curator page for more reviews on indies like this, which helps.

[code] https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42143664/ [/code]

147314075.review:
This is a very special game. It's one of those rare perfect short experiences like Portal, Inside and Abzu. The art style is super cool and the game has some amazing views. The puzzles were all interesting and managed to strike that balance between occasionally stumping you, but never frustrating you. It's a short game, taking me just over 4 hours to finish, but in this age where most major releases are 50+ hour investments, it was a breath of fresh air.
You can tell a ton of passion went into Cocoon, and it really paid off. Feels like it came out of nowhere and now it's a strong contender for my GOTY, right alongside titans like TOTK and RE4. If you're even just a little interested in this game, I very highly recommend you check it out. Wonderful experience I won't be forgetting anytime soon.

147313922.review:
What an absolute gem of a game. I played through it in one sitting, simply because I couldn't stop playing.
Perfect length. Very interesting puzzles.
The whole game feels so polished and I hit no bugs or glitches at all.

Don't hesitate to buy this, if you like puzzle games.

147313646.review:
In a world that’s still debating whether or not Starfield is a good game (I’ll spare you my opinion on that, because it isn’t pretty), Geometric drops the most elegant and enchanting game I’ve played in years. 

The controls are incredibly smooth, the sense of mystery is out of this world, the visuals and soundscape are godlike, the puzzles are challenging but fair, and the boss battles are among the most beautifully animated you’ll ever see. 

Dropping balls into digestive tracts may be frowned upon by some, but for me it’s the icing on the cake in what may very well be the best game of 2023.

147313413.review:
COCOON is a fantastic game that I have been looking forward to since the minute it was announced and I am happy to let you know that my expectations were met and exceeded and if you don't want to read any further, I can not recommend this game enough!

I have always been a huge fan of Jeppe Carlsen's work. LIMBO and INSIDE by Playdead are both excellent games, but also his lesser known solo work, 140 and THOTH are terrific in their own right. If you have played the latter, you might remember my name from one of the achievements. I even had the honor of meeting Jeppe Carlsen, Jakob Schmid and some other (ex-)Playdead folk and I still cherish the memories of that night.

When I heard that Carlsen had left Playdead to start his own studio, I was sad on one hand, because I had valued his puzzle design of their games as feeling integral to the world. But on the other hand, I felt excited for what was to come.

Knowing Carlsen's work well, I expected this game to put a huge emphasis on game feel and intuitive player guidance with excellent sound design and music integration. And this is pretty much what I got, but I did not, even after watching the trailers, expect this game to look so absolutely gorgeous all of the time on screen.

The game controls nice and fluid, everything can be done with eight directions and a single button. If you play on controller, you have analog movement controls but your character's idle animation can only appear in said eight directions. The music is more calm and atmospheric but there are occasional intense sections in the soundtrack, fitting the action on screen.

What really boggles my mind is the puzzle design. Knowing Carlsen, I did not expect any less, but the way in which mechanics are introduced to the player, consecutively in didactically designed challenges to the point where it feels completely natural to come up with the solution for the next puzzle made me speechless. There was never a time in the game where I felt lost or stuck, I always had the drive forward but at the same time, the puzzles always provided the right amount of challenge to me and did not seem trivial to solve.

There are very few very, very minor nitpicks that I still feel obliged to state here. The game starts with a "cold start" opening which is always cool, but from the player perspective, specifically on PC not always the best, since it prevents players from checking the game’s settings. As a result, the game started, at least for me, in 1080p and 60fps despite my monitor supporting 1440p 144fps and these gorgeous graphics deserve the crispest resolution you can offer them. The other slight issue I found was that some more frequent actions needed a held button press which felt just a tiny tad too long for my taste, to the point where I felt a slight bit of annoyance when I needed to do them often in succession. But as I said, these are absolute minor nitpicks, and the graphics options in the cold start can hopefully be fixed in a future patch.

Other than that, I have absolutely nothing negative to say about this game. Its length and dramaturgical development with environmental storytelling combined with gameplay make for definitely the most compelling experience, by far, I've had with any game I played this year.

Very highly recommended.

147313001.review:
Absolutely stunning visuals
Mindblowing puzzle mechanics
Amazing sound design and music

10/10 highly recommended

147312621.review:
Cocoon is a fantastic piece of art but a relatively poor product. The game is well made, creative, and extremely polished, but also very short. At around 3-4 hours to see the credits and $32 Can ($24 USD) price tag this is a premium experience. If you have cash to spare I can't recommend this game enough, but if you are worried about the $ to time spent equation this is a wait for a steep discount game.  

I played on the steam deck and while not currently verified this game is a match made in heaven for a handheld console. The game ran flawlessly besides some noticeable fps drops in 2 cut scenes. These performance issues had no impact on game play. The only bugs I encountered are the intended ones such as the main character.

147312031.review:
The puzzle/level design here is superb, head-scratching but not bruising. There's an almost nonstop variety of ideas; some conventional, many unlike anything else I've seen in a game before. I'd say it falters only the slightest bit when you're doing the sections that require you to activate symbols in the correct order, but even those aren't carbon copies of each other. Immersion has been polished to basically perfection, with zero loading screens after the first boot-up, unintrusive controls, and incredible sounding atmosphere and music. 

I would've loved a standout challenging final boss after how cool the previous ones were, though I was very satisfied with how the game wrapped up regardless. Any game that has excellent artistic merit while refusing to deprive us of creative and interesting gameplay should be praised.

147310435.review:
Wonderful. I love the aesthetic, the soundtrack (incredible sound design btw), and the feeling this game gives you overall. The mix between organic and mechanical is incredibly well made and creative; everything feels so alive, literally. It achieves everything it wants to do, and it does so perfectly.

If you liked TUNIC, you'll most likely enjoy this game as well; they share quite a few similarities. This game has less combat, and has much simpler controls, but when there [i] is [/i] combat it feels polished and is extremely enjoyable. It's relaxing, stressful, creepy, dreadful, and cute all at once. This game deserves so much love.

147307837.review:
The start seems a bit too simple for me, but it does pick up in complexity. I had hoped, it would be more like a pure puzzle game (somewhat like Patrick's Parabox maybe), but it's more of an adventure/exploration game with puzzles.
What bothers me is that the game won't let you experiment much. After solving a puzzle, you can't interact with the elements anymore, because they straight up dissolve or bridges and gates get closed. It feels a bit too guided for me because of this.
I'm not sure if it's too short, or if it's just right in length for what it is. [spoiler]The purple sphere wasn't utilized that much, especially in the end part of the game, which is kind of odd. It probably would have been more satisfying if it was used again[/spoiler]
[spoiler]There are also boss fights for some reason, lol. Didn't expect that at all, but they're also just puzzles with a fail state.[/spoiler]

The art and sound direction and the whole atmosphere of the game in general are absolutely phenomenal, though. Very very alien, with shapes, nobody could have ever imagined.

Overall pretty decent game.

147305076.review: just a fun time playing with your balls

147304837.review: Short but sweet puzzle game with beautiful graphics and music.

147303985.review: Absolutely love it! I had very high expectations from the first trailer and the game exceeded each and every one of them. Great job, you should be proud of what you've accomplished. It's an instant classic for me, the gameplay, music, design, it's all in perfect tune!

147303197.review:
So far, I've acquired 3 orbs (orange, green, and purple) and defeated each of their bosses.  The worlds and puzzle designs are outstanding.  Truly phenomenal. I don't know how many orbs there are total... but I'm incredibly excited to find out.  This is easily in the top 3 games I've played this year (out of 100+).  

My only, minor, complaint is that there are a LOT of intentional wrong pathways for no real reason except to let you "explore"... but they feel tedious more than any possible benefit.

EDIT: Game completed.  Took 3.6 hours, as per Steam.  Finding the White orb is roughly the halfway point, I'd say.  Absolutely incredible game. 10/10.  Must play.  Good luck and have fun!

147302685.review: I'm sure I've only scratched the surface so far but puzzle solving in this game is cool in a way that I last saw in Can of wormholes, Patrick's parabox and Baba is you

147300760.review: I've been looking forward to this game for so long, after being massive fans of 140 and THOTH by Jeppe Carlsen and Jakob Schmid. This game is above and beyond what the trailers made me think. Every puzzle makes you go "whoa, I never thought that mechanic could be used in that way." The game's visuals are stellar; art style is impeccable. Sound design and music are ALWAYS on point in a Schmid game. I cannot recommend this game enough.

147299936.review:
This is the strangest and most alien metroidvania I've ever seen. Original puzzles, interesting art style, fun to discover new mechanics. I believe we've got a winner.

I highly recommend.

Edit: After playing a bit more I think I made a mistake and it's not actually a metroidvania since I haven't seen a need to or possibility of backtracking across the whole game.

147299698.review:
The game is designed beautifully.
It is intricate and challenging.
Absolutely love it.

147291648.review:
This'll be one of the first reviews for COCOON on here, and just for that reason I want to say to anyone feeling caught - on either side - of this so-called "Culture War" that things are going to get BETTER, not WORSE.

It's not on the media or our politicians to determine how we are or how we treat each other. for whatever that's worth, that's what I believe. 

I've been waiting for this one for a bit - and if I don't think it'll top INSIDE, that's only because I don't know if any game like this could. 15 minutes into it I doubt there's been a game like this I'm more certain I'll dig. 

sorry for the social semantics, and cue the clowns and slow claps, but it's just what I think: we'll get better, not worse -- no matter which way the media winds are spinning. I believe that, and I hope you do, too. 

peace to both sides of this ridiculous #CulturalConversation. it's what a game like this brings out of people. (or maybe just CORNY people. laff.) 

-b in Fall 23

147385156.review:

147383616.review:
this game didnt make my brain hurt. its not that puzzly, in fact at times it deviates from puzzles completely which in my playthrough was a little bit anoying. it tries to be two radically diferent things at once and it kinda does an acceptable job at both, but it doesnt excell at neither. 

i imagine people that dont normally play puzzle games might actually find this challenging, but if you are experienced in puzzle games, you migth get bored of how linear and straigth forward this game is (altough i must admit there is like 3 actually good puzzles in the game, most of them are not that interesting at all)

In terms of the aesthetics though, this game easily enters in my top 10 best looking and sounding games i've ever played. so if cool graphics, straight forward puzzles and lame bossfigths are enough for you i recomend you try this game.

If what you are looking for however, is good puzzles, i recommend you try The Witness first.
